content.description: The crux for me was near the start, getting up above the gap and into the crack.
content.location: At the right end of the roof, there is a gap with a vertical crack above it.  This is in between Bolt Line and the large block under Ariel's Brassiere.

content.description: The line in between little necky and dirtissima

This route is also known as Little Neck-y.

 Start far right, edging left; after 10 feet, climb directly up the obvious crack another 15 ft, after a small tree, ascend directly to the route's crux well above the tree (60 ft). Pull up and over a small bulge, finding many slots for good pro placements and jugs all the way to the top, where a final difficult move awaits. Interesting holds on "clamshell" rocks, requiring much open grip work. Crack is on-width most of the route, making the middle section more like 5.5 or 5.4 climbing.
content.protection: Standard Gunks rack. Two ringed rap bolts are located at the top of the route, set up to make rapping off a snap.
content.location: The start of the route is to the far right of the wall, where there is some lichen and moss (which generally fades as you ascend). Watch for loose snake skin in holds!

content.description: Leftmost line on the Clamshell Wall. Heel hook the opening crux off the big boulder, clip the bolt (stick clip might be advisable, though you can place a small cam at the lip before beginning). Move left on easy ground and blast to the top up a clean strip of white rock. Second mini-crux near the top.
content.protection: There are two bolts at the top of the route but they are BELOW the actual top. You can lean over to set up a TR but rapping from there is not a good idea at all. Topping out above the bolts is safe but would certainly add another crux.
content.location: If you don't like the big starting move, step off the right end of the block to the hanging corner (this is the start of Ariel's Brassiere) then go hard left to join Hooker. Done this way, it's a very fun 5.8.

content.description: The rightmost route on the clamshell wall before the scramble-up section. It’s often wet after rain.
content.protection: PG, double-bolted anchor w/ rings at the top
content.location: Look for a dirt line right before the scramble at the clamshell wall

content.description: Start just to the right of a bolt 10 feet up, and climb on tenuous slopers past the bolt and left until you reach a thin crack. Follow this crack up and right as it widens until you reach a false topout. Continue up more slopers to gain a second crack which leads to a bolted anchor.
content.protection: PG, double-bolted anchor w/ rings at the top
content.location: Start near the bolt, just to the right of a large bush at the base of the wall.

content.description:
If you are on top rope climbing toward the bolts, the top is very thin.  There are good holds to the left in a triangular recess, but you'd be at risk of swinging from there. 

  The start was a bit nervy, as you step across from the block to the face.
content.location: Start on the top of a large block; from the right side, move across to the face.

content.description: This is the tall, mostly grey face, with many horizontals that resembles the Trapps. The left end of it starts 7 ft above a large rectangular boulder. There are about 8 distinct lines that mostly follow vertical cracks/grooves and 3 bolted anchors at the top, though these may not be in the spots that get the most traffic. Two are on the left, one ledge system below the top. The other is on top at the right end.
